DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Condemns U.S. Invasion of Panama
Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with TV news coverage. Pickup 8th pvs, ``Bush said...''
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Wednesday branded the U.S. military attack in Panama ``gunboat diplomacy'' and a violation of international law. It called for an immediate end to the operation. However, a Soviet official played down any impact the U.S. action might have on improved superpower relations, and the Kremlin's rhetoric was far milder than its denunciations of the 1983 U.S. invasion of Grenada. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliev told a news briefing the sending of U.S. troops to Panama, ``whatever its motivation, has provoked a feeling of serious concern in the Soviet Union.'' He said the U.S. action violated the U.N. Charter and recognized rules of international relations and ``should be condemned by the international community.'' The United States, he said, ``must immediately stop its armed intervention in Panama.'' Millions of Soviets saw dramatic footage of the attack on the nightly TV newscast ``Vremya.'' Commentator Igor Fyesunenko: ``Again, the world hears the loud voice of `gunboat diplomacy' and understands perfectly well that the anger of Washington is caused not by the American concern about Panama, but by the wish to disrupt the process of transferrence of the ownership rights of the (Panama) canal ... and to preserve the complex of American military bases on the territory of this country,'' he said. Tass said none of the arguments put forth by President Bush to justify the military operation stands up to scrutiny. ``This action is an example of notorious `gunboat diplomacy' which has been used for decades by the United States in an attempt to turn Latin American and Caribbean nations into its backyard,'' the official news agency said. Bush said the troops were sent to protect U.S. lives and apprehend Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who stands accused by Washington of setting up a succession of puppet regimes while running a military empire that purportedly trafficked in Colombian cocaine. Perfiliev dismissed the allegations of drug trafficking as a pretext to intervene in Panamanian affairs. The Soviet Union is steadfastly against international drug trafficking, he said, reflecting the Soviets' greater attention under leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to global problems that were once dismissed as symptoms of capitalist decay. ``We have something else here,'' Perfiliev said. ``We are commenting on the intervention of the United States in a sovereign state. No matter what the motivation, this is something we are very concerned about.'' Despite Soviet concern, Perfiliev indicated the U.S. action would not reverse the direction of improved Soviet-U.S. relations. ``We are now in a situation where an event in the East or in the West is not perceived, is not evaluated, in terms of confrontation between East and West,'' the Soviet spokesman said. But, he said, ``I think both the Soviet Union and the United States would stand to gain if a situation could be achieved where there is not interference in the affairs of others.'' Tass, however, said sending U.S. troops to Panama did not involve just another regional conflict. ``It is a dangerous encroachment on the unsteady equilibrium that has been achieved in the world arena,'' it said. The United States, it said, ``has challenged the entire international community and is acting against universal human interests.'' Official Soviet reaction to the U.S. actions in Panama was markedly more restrained than when former President Ronald Reagan ordered the invasion of Grenada in 1983. At that time, the government newspaper Izvestia accused the United States of carrying out ``a stinking show.'' It also said Reagan was ``obsessed with the ideas of world domination.'' Perfiliev said all countries would benefit from policies of non-interference, which the Soviet leadership under Gorbachev has repeatedly professed to be its policy. ``All states would stand to gain when all peoples of all countries decide their own destinies,'' Perfiliev said.
